commit_list.message:
Remove common eslint warnings from jest.js (#507)

* Fix method chaining for signatures that support it

* Before my chaining fixes, these test changes would result in these errors:

 * jest_v17.x.x/flow_>=v0.33.x (flow-v0.36.0): Unexpected Flow errors(2):
   0-test_jest-v17.x.x.js:71
    71: jest
        ^ call of method `doMock`. Method cannot be called on possibly undefined value
    71: jest
        ^ undefined

   0-test_jest-v17.x.x.js:75
    75: jest
        ^ call of method `dontMock`. Method cannot be called on possibly undefined value
    75: jest
        ^ undefined

   0-test_jest-v17.x.x.js:79
    79: jest
        ^ call of method `resetModules`. Method cannot be called on possibly undefined value
    79: jest
        ^ undefined

   Found 3 errors

   null

With my chaining fixes, the test passes.

* eslint warning: 'Prefer commas to semicolons in object and class types'

* eslint warning: 'Line NNN exceeds the maximum line length of 80.'

* eslint warning: 'Source code should only include printable US-ASCII bytes. Use Unicode escapes like \u to represent non-US-ASCII values.'

* eslint warning: 'Use `Array<mixed>` instead of `mixed[]`.'

commit_list.message: Initial example

Modified to work better on Windows

Currently, yamlhead chokes on the initial "---" found in jekyll templates if they were created on Windows, since the newline character can be '\r\n'.

While I was at it, I updated the code to allow the jekyll leading "---" to have trailing whitespace as well.

commit_list.message:
Add new test fixtures which expose bug in ordering test
Added 2 test fixtures, testb.js and testz.js, to the 'dir' directory. These files expose the lack of determinism in how Uglify is being passed the list of files, even when the ordering parameter is passed. It is only ordering by directory, not by filename, so the tests sometimes pass and sometimes they don't.

commit_list.message:
Bundle size stats + Misc changes

Summary:
**Summary**

Misc changes that:
1. Make the dev environment work on Windows and Node v9.
1. Upgrade Webpack and UglifyJS.
1. Build now outputs build stats to the `meta/bundle-size-stats directory/` dir.
    1. The build stats are named the current package version, e.g. the current one is `version-0.10.5.json`.
    1. An example of this file can be seen here: https://files.terriblefish.com/version-0.10.5.json
    1. This json file can be visualized in any of the various tools online, e.g. [the official tool](https://webpack.github.io/analyse) which is great for visualizing module dependencies and [this one from Chris Bateman](http://chrisbateman.github.io/webpack-visualizer/) that makes visualizing file sizes really nice.

**Test Plan**

`npm test`, `npm run lint`, and `npm run flow` all pass

**Misc**
* I don't think any of these changes need tests
* No API changes
Closes https://github.com/facebook/draft-js/pull/1644

Reviewed By: flarnie

Differential Revision: D6950926

Pulled By: flarnie

fbshipit-source-id: 47de3b030087af010a19694caeca3de13d16a099
commit_list.repo_description: A React framework for building text editors.

commit_list.message:
Bundle size stats

Summary:
By naming bundle size stats with the bundle name instead of the package version:
  - `yarn build` will produce stats for both the development bundle
    (Draft.js.json) and the production bundle (Draft.min.js.json) which we can
    track separately. The minified bundle is good for understanding what file
    size we will be advertising (albeit pre-gzip/brotli) while the development version
    is useful for seeing a 1:1 mapping between changes in code and bundle size.
  - The size stats will get overwritten everytime somebody builds and checks in,
    but that is desirable. Instead of keeping the entire history of the bundle
    size always checked-in (and possibly not in sync with the actual versions),
    git will keep track of the bundle size over time. Whenever we release, the
    size of the stats file for that release is whatever is in Draft.min.js.json
    at the time of release.

Here are the separate bundles (as visualized by
https://chrisbateman.github.io/webpack-visualizer/):

Development: https://files.terriblefish.com/chrome_2018-02-16_12-11-22.png
Production: https://files.terriblefish.com/chrome_2018-02-16_12-12-01.png

`yarn test`, `yarn run lint`, and `yarn run flow` all pass.
Closes https://github.com/facebook/draft-js/pull/1654

Reviewed By: flarnie

Differential Revision: D7073462

Pulled By: flarnie

fbshipit-source-id: 64cbad2dcaf93641ff932a63aaa47e59d86c9df7

Added typings for page - https://www.npmjs.com/package/page - Tiny client-side router

Remove maskBaseDir and destPrefix options

I've replaced the plugin's current technique of taking an array of
sources and options to generate the destination with support for the
standard Grunt source/destination mapping.

The maskBaseDir and destPrefix options required users to learn
options specific to this task that could be accomplished using Grunt's
standardized file mapping utilities instead. Allowing the user to use
Grunt's file configuration means:
    1. The user doesn't have to learn something new.
    2. The user can weild Grunt's much more powerful options.
    3. There is less code in the plugin.

For example, these are equivalent:

Old way, using makeBaseDir and destPrefix:

    css: {
      options: {
        destPrefix: '<%= pkg.version %>/'
        maskBaseDir: '../web/Content/'
      },
      src: ['../web/Content/**/*','!../web/Content/themes/**/*']
    }

New way, using standard Grunt conventions:

    css: {
      files: [{
        expand: true,
        cwd: '../web/Content',
        dest: '<%= pkg.version %>/',
        src: ['**/*', '!themes/**/*']
      }]
    }

commit_list.message:
Make 10 uploads at a time plus misc minor changes

- My editor stripped trailing spaces. Please forgive me :)
- There were also some minor spacing/indentation inconsistencies I
  fixed.
- Changed behavior to upload 10 files at a time instead of uploading
  each file one at a time.  This *drastically* improves performance of
  the task.
- Added maxNumberOfConcurrentUploads option which defaults to 10 to
  control the above behavior.
- There were two 'latedef' entries in .jshintrc file. In addition to
  removing the redundant one, I sorted them to make such a future
  mistake less likely.

commit_list.message:
Check-in package-lock.json

package-lock.json, used by newer npm for deterministic installs, is intended to be checked-in. See https://github.com/npm/npm/blob/v5.0.0/doc/files/package-lock.json.md#description for more info.
commit_list.repo_description: CLI to convert CommonJS to ES6 modules

commit_list.message:
Upgrade to child-process-promise@2.2.1 to support Windows

The latest version of child-process-promise supports Windows by using the cross-spawn library instead of relying on `require('child_process').spawn` directly (see https://github.com/patrick-steele-idem/child-process-promise/pull/28).
commit_list.repo_description: CLI to convert CommonJS to ES6 modules

commit_list.message:
Add support to specify a custom parser for jscodeshift

cjs-to-es6 cannot currently run on flow-typed files. We can add support for flow-typed files by allowing the user to specify what parser jscodeshift should use. Verified this works by running: `node .\index.js --parser flow --verbose flow-typed-js-file.js`

commit_list.message:
Added handlebars 3 support as a peerDependency.  Doesn't appear to require any code changes, as:
1) Tests still pass for this loader
2) Tests still pass for my project that uses this loader
3) A skim of the handlebars release notes does not indicate anything backwards compatible breaking as far as this loader is concerned.

NOTE: JavaScriptCompiler is now a public, documented API but this loader isn't yet aligned with that API.  Someone can either submit a pull request or I'll wait till the loader breaks and then fix it. (+1 squashed commits)

Squashed commits:

[3c0ad2b] 1.0.0

- Switched handlebars from a dependency to a peer-dependency.
